thread.title_full: Court Is Asked to Reconsider N.C.A.A. Case - The New York Times

author: Ben Strauss
title: Court Is Asked to Reconsider N.C.A.A. Case
text:
Lawyers for a group of former college athletes have asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to review its decision that upheld N.C.A.A. rules prohibiting payments to college athletes.
In documents filed Wednesday, the lawyers asked the court for an en banc hearing — essentially an appeal that would be heard by a larger group of judges from the Ninth Circuit than the three who issued last month’s ruling.
Continue reading the main story Related Coverage Court Strikes Down Payments to College Athletes SEPT. 30, 2015 Court Grants Stay in O’Bannon Case JULY 31, 2015 Catching Up With the O’Bannon Ruling, Soon to Go Into Effect JULY 29, 2015 Continue reading the main story Related in Opinion Op-Ed Columnist: O’Bannon’s Hollow Victory Over the N.C.A.A. OCT. 2, 2015 The appellate court’s recent decision affirmed part of a federal judge’s ruling in the so-called O’Bannon case — that the N.C.A.A. broke antitrust laws by not allowing athletes to profit from the use of their images on TV and in video games. But it also ruled that the enhanced scholarships the N.C.A.A. approved this year and are worth an extra few thousand dollars were sufficient to remedy the antitrust harm. In a 2-to-1 decision, the appellate court threw out the deferred payments suggested by the district court that would have allowed colleges to pay athletes up to $5,000 per year.
The N.C.A.A. appealed the lower court’s decision to the Ninth Circuit, but now the athletes’ lawyers are arguing that the appellate court acted improperly.
The Ninth Circuit has about six weeks to consider whether to accept the petition. If it does, an 11-judge panel will be convened to reconsider the N.C.A.A.’s appeal of the district court’s ruling.
